articles.author: KIM TONG-HYUNG and DASHA LITVINOVA
articles.description: SEOUL, South Korea (AP) — North Korea’s Kim Jong Un vowed “full and unconditional support” for Russia’s Vladimir Putin on Wednesday as the two leaders isolated by the West held a summit that the U.S.
articles.title: North Korea's Kim vows full support for Russia at summit with Putin at a Far East spaceport

articles.author: SAMY MAGDY and YOUSEF MURAD
articles.description: DERNA, Libya (AP) — The death toll from flooding that hit the eastern Libyan city of Derna reached more than 5,100 and was expected to rise further, a local health official said Wednesday, as authorities struggled to get aid to the coastal city where thousands remained missing and tens of thousands were homeless.
articles.title: Toll from devastating floods in Libyan city passes 5,100 dead, authorities struggle to get in aid

articles.author: LISA MASCARO and FARNOUSH AMIRI
articles.description: WASHINGTON (AP) — Speaker Kevin McCarthy announced Tuesday he is directing the U.S.
articles.title: Speaker McCarthy directs the House to open an impeachment inquiry into President Biden

articles.author: SAM METZ and MOSA'AB ELSHAMY
articles.description: IMI N'TALA, Morocco (AP) — The stench of death wafted through the village of Imi N’Tala high up in Morocco’s Atlas Mountains four days after a deadly earthquake struck, slicing off a chunk of mountain, killing residents and razing the hamlet to the ground.
articles.title: International crews in Morocco to recover bodies days after deadly 6.8 quake earthquake struck

articles.author: DASHA LITVINOVA and ILLIA NOVIKOV
articles.description: KYIV, Ukraine (AP) — A Ukrainian attack on a strategic shipyard early Wednesday in Russia-annexed Crimea wounded 24 people, damaged two ships undergoing repairs and caused a fire at the facility, Russian authorities reported.
articles.title: A Crimea shipyard is on fire after a Ukrainian attack that damaged 2 ships and injured 24 people

articles.author: TIA GOLDENBERG
articles.description: HERZLIYA, Israel (AP) — They contended with bloody uprisings, destabilizing wars and even the assassination of a prime minister during their service. But for dozens of former Israeli security commanders, the policies of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s far-right government are the biggest threat yet to the country’s future.
articles.title: Former leaders of Israel's security services are speaking out against Netanyahu's policies

articles.author: TOM KRISHER
articles.description: DETROIT (AP) — Leaders of the United Auto Workers union are considering targeted strikes at a small number of factories run by each of Detroit’s three automakers if they can’t reach contract agreements by a Thursday night deadline.
articles.title: AP Sources: UAW may strike at small number of factories if it can't reach deals with automakers

articles.author: MARY CLARE JALONICK and MATT O'BRIEN
articles.description: WASHINGTON (AP) — Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer has been talking for months about accomplishing a potentially impossible task: passing bipartisan legislation within the next year that encourages the rapid development of artificial intelligence and mitigates its biggest risks.
articles.title: Tech titans will give senators advice on artificial intelligence in a closed-door forum

articles.author: MARÍA VERZA and MADDIE BURAKOFF
articles.description: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras (AP) — For decades, preventing dengue fever in Honduras has meant teaching people to fear mosquitoes and avoid their bites. Now, Hondurans are being educated about a potentially more effective way to control the disease — and it goes against everything they’ve learned.
articles.title: Special mosquitoes are being bred to fight dengue. How the old enemies are now becoming allies

articles.description: PARIS (AP) — A government watchdog agency in France has ordered Apple to withdraw the iPhone 12 from the French market, saying it emits levels of electromagnetic radiation that are too high.
articles.title: The iPhone 12 emits too much radiation and Apple must take it off the market, a French agency says
